If a client objects to purchasing an annuity because of the fees, here are some ways you could address their concerns:

1. Explain the benefits of an annuity: Annuities can offer several benefits, including a guaranteed income stream, tax-deferred growth, and protection against market downturns. By explaining the benefits of an annuity, you can help the client see the value in paying the fees.
2. Compare the fees to other investments: While annuities may have higher fees than other investments, they also offer unique benefits that other investments may not provide. By comparing the fees to other investment options, you can help the client see that the fees may be worth paying for the benefits they receive.
3. Discuss the specific fees associated with the annuity: Annuities can have several different types of fees, including surrender charges, mortality and expense fees, and administrative fees. By discussing the specific fees associated with the annuity, you can help the client understand what they are paying for and how much they can expect to pay.
4. Offer lower-fee alternatives: If the client is still concerned about the fees, you could offer lower-fee alternatives, such as a no-load mutual fund or an index fund. While these options may not offer the same benefits as an annuity, they can still be a good option for clients who are fee-sensitive.
5. Negotiate with the insurance company: Some insurance companies may be willing to negotiate on fees, especially for larger investments. If the client is interested in purchasing an annuity but is concerned about the fees, you could reach out to the insurance company to see if they are willing to lower the fees.
